title: PROOF: The Affirmative Action Committee's Formation Was a Foundational Breach of the 2020 DNC MOU, Rendering It Illegitimate at Inception
stakes: The promise of representation for West Virginia's minority communities was broken at its inception, disenfranchising the very groups the MOU was meant to empower and guaranteeing the failure of the entire diversity initiative.
thesis: The WVDP and DNC's RBC violated the 2020 MOU by using a secret script to install a pre-selected leadership slate, creating an illegitimate committee that was structurally designed to fail.

axioms.text: The Caucus-First Mandate: The MOU required that the Affirmative Action Committee be formed with members 'selected by their particular caucus.'
The State Party's Duty to Implement: The MOU mandated that the State Party 'fully implement... the creation of any new... caucuses.'
The RBC's Duty to Supervise: The MOU explicitly required that the entire implementation process be conducted 'under the supervision... of representatives of the RBC.'

rule_summary: These rules established a mandatory, non-negotiable sequence—a blueprint for legitimacy. The MOU required that caucuses be formed first to select their own representatives, who would then constitute the committee. Any other process was a direct breach of the agreement's core terms, and the RBC was the designated supervisor responsible for enforcing that blueprint.

case_facts.text: The committee's formation was orchestrated in secret using a non-public script, circulated with the explicit instruction 'do not share,' proving the process was designed to be non-transparent.

The script's author(s) proceeded with full knowledge that their plan excluded the majority of required diversity groups, as the document itself admits the committee was 'missing representation from... Latino's, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders, and Native Americans.'
To ensure control, the script pre-emptively installed a hand-picked leadership slate, nullifying the right of the yet-to-be-formed caucuses to participate in selecting their own leadership.

The script's author, Selina Vickers, cemented procedural control by orchestrating her own self-appointment to the role of Parliamentarian, complete with a pre-written endorsement calling her uniquely qualified.

logic_chain: The MOU promised a legitimate, caucus-driven process for forming the AAC under the watchful eye of the DNC's RBC.
Instead, the State Party, guided by a secret script, deliberately subverted this promise.
This subversion was intentional, as the script's own text proves the organizers knew they were excluding 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses.
By pre-emptively installing leadership, they disenfranchised these minority groups at the committee's inception.
This foundational breach occurred under the mandated supervision of the DNC's RBC, which failed its duty to enforce the MOU's terms.
[DJ-MARK] The result was not an authentic committee, but an illegitimate body born from a rigged process, directly violating the 2020 MOU.
violation: The WVDP's implementation and the RBC's supervisory failure constituted a foundational breach of contract and trust. They violated the MOU's core 'caucus-first mandate' by knowingly creating an unaccountable committee through a secretive, pre-arranged process. This initial, deliberate act of disenfranchisement rendered the Affirmative Action Committee illegitimate at the moment of its creation and doomed the entire diversity initiative to fail.

title: PROOF: Organizers Excluded Racial Caucuses Through Selective Non-Formation
stakes: Three of the four mandated racial minority communities were disenfranchised from the committee's formation, proving that the process was not merely flawed, but strategically engineered to exclude specific groups from participation.
thesis: The failure to form 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses was a strategic exclusion, not an administrative oversight, evidenced by the organizers' simultaneous success in forming allied caucuses and their targeted interference in the formation of disfavored caucuses.

axioms.text: The 2020 MOU's stated purpose was 'to create a process to establish new, and assist currently existing, diversity caucuses'.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 1

axioms.text: The MOU mandated that the State Party 'fully implement... the creation of any new... caucuses.'

rule_summary: The MOU placed a direct and non-negotiable responsibility on the state party and its organizers to 'fully implement' the creation of new diversity caucuses. A failure to form these caucuses constitutes a direct breach of this core mandate.

case_facts.text: Prior to the AAC leadership installation, 75% of the DNC-mandated racial diversity caucuses (AAPI, Latino, Native American) had not been formed.
During this same period, organizers successfully formed other non-racial diversity caucuses

The Co-chair of the Black Caucus, Mary Claytor, stated that organizer Selina Vickers 'contacted every member of the Indigenous Caucus not named Sturm prior to their nomination meeting' and 'refused' a request to contact the Sturms. [cite: 57, 58, 59]
The Indigenous Caucus was subsequently denied seats on the planning and bylaws subcommittees. [cite: 48]

logic_chain: The MOU required the formation of four specific racial diversity caucuses.
Organizers failed to form three of these four caucuses before installing the committee's leadership.
This failure cannot be attributed to a lack of time or ability, as they successfully formed other caucuses for their allies in the same timeframe.
Evidence shows organizers also actively interfered in the formation of at least one of these caucuses (Indigenous) by selectively contacting members.
The subsequent exclusion of that caucus from subcommittees reveals a pattern of disenfranchisement originating at the formation stage.
[DJ-MARK] The selective non-formation, combined with active interference, proves the disenfranchisement of three racial minority caucuses was a deliberate and strategic act.
violation: By failing to form 75% of the mandated racial diversity caucuses while simultaneously forming others and interfering in the process, organizers violated the MOU's requirement to 'fully implement' the caucus creation process. This selective failure was a strategic act of disenfranchisement that rendered the committee's formation illegitimate.

title: PROOF: Script's Detail Proves Deliberate Exclusion of Mandated Caucuses
stakes: By proceeding without 75% of its required racial diversity caucuses, the committee's foundational decisions, including the election of its leadership, were rendered illegitimate.
thesis: The formation script's detail proves the organizers strategically excluded 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses, a deliberate violation of the DNC MOU.

axioms.text: The 2020 DNC MOU required the creation of an Affirmative Action Committee ('AA Committee') to include members from each diversity group... selected by their particular caucus.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2-3

axioms.text: The mandated diversity groups included African Americans, Native Americans, Asian/Pacific Islanders, and Latinos.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

rule_summary: The MOU, as the governing agreement, established a mandatory sequence: 1) The party must facilitate the formation of specific diversity caucuses. 2) Those caucuses must select their own representatives. 3) Those representatives must then constitute the AA Committee. The committee's legitimacy was wholly dependent on the prior existence and participation of these groups.

case_facts.text: The script for the June 2, 2021 meeting demonstrates micro-level control, dictating specific nominators, providing verbatim speeches, and planning for procedural disruptions.

The script proves the organizers knew 75% of the racial caucuses did not exist, as it includes a future resolution to 'do outreach to Latinos, Asian Americans/Pacific Islanders and Native Americans to facilitate those groups in forming their own diversity caucuses'.

The script designates a specific individual, Kim Felix, to be nominated for an at-large diversity seat 'representing Latino Americans', proving the organizers had identified potential leadership for a caucus they had not yet formed.

logic_chain: The organizers demonstrated a high capacity for detailed organizational planning, as evidenced by the script.
The organizers possessed documented knowledge that the Latino, AAPI, and Native American caucuses had not been formed as required by the MOU.
When contrasted with their failure to form the required caucuses, the organizers' meticulous planning proves the exclusion was intentional.
Therefore, the decision to proceed with the AAC's formation was a deliberate choice to exclude 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses from selecting leadership.
[DJ-MARK] The organizers deliberately violated the MOU by choosing exclusion over inclusion.
violation: The organizers deliberately violated the 2020 DNC MOU by forming the AAC while knowingly excluding 75% of the required racial diversity caucuses. The script's detail proves this was a calculated act of disenfranchisement—not an administrative failure—that breached the agreement's core terms.

title: PROOF: Secret Script Subverted MOU with Preferential Nomination
stakes: By providing a preferential, pre-arranged nomination for one hand-picked individual while sidelining other minority groups, organizers created a two-tiered system that violated the democratic principles of the MOU, ensuring their preferred slate would be installed.
thesis: Organizers violated the MOU's principle of a fair and equal selection process by using a secret script to install a pre-arranged slate, which included a preferential nomination for a hand-picked individual to 'represent' the Latino community.

axioms.text: The 2020 DNC MOU required that members of the Affirmative Action Committee be 'selected by their particular caucus.'

rule_summary: The MOU's requirement that representatives be 'selected by their particular caucus' implies a fair, equal, and democratic process for all caucuses. A system that uses a secret script to impose a pre-arranged slate, including a privileged nomination for one individual, fundamentally violates this principle of fairness.

case_facts.text: Selina Vickers circulated a script for the formation meeting with the subject line 'DRAFT SCRIPT - do not share.'
The script contained a verbatim sequence for leadership nominations, including 'Mary Ann nominates Hollis Lewis.'
The script also directed a nomination for Kim Felix for the 'at-large diversity seat representing Latino Americans.'
The script did not contain similar at-large nominations for the AAPI or Native American communities, groups the document itself noted were 'missing representation.'

logic_chain: The MOU requires a fair and democratic selection process for all caucuses.
A secret script with a 'do not share' instruction proves the organizers' intent to control the process undemocratically.
The script dictated the entire leadership slate, making a genuine 'selection' by any caucus impossible.
The preferential nomination for one individual is the clearest example of this rigged, two-tiered system.
[DJ-MARK] The rigged nomination process was fundamentally undemocratic and violated the spirit and letter of the MOU.
violation: By using a secret script to impose a pre-arranged slate and provide a preferential nomination to a pre-selected individual, organizers violated the democratic principles of the MOU. This act of favoritism created an unequal and unfair process, subverting the right of all caucuses to genuinely select their representatives and rendering the outcome of the formation meeting illegitimate.

title: PROOF: MOU Compliance Officer Breached Duty by Orchestrating Her Own Appointment
stakes: The official tasked by the MOU with guaranteeing a fair and open process instead corrupted it for personal gain, fundamentally invalidating the legitimacy of the committee's procedural foundation.
thesis: As the appointed MOU compliance officer, Selina Vickers breached her duty to ensure a fair process by authoring a secret script that orchestrated her own installation into the powerful role of Parliamentarian.

axioms.text: The MOU appointed a non-elected official, Selina Vickers, to 'oversee and direct compliance' with the agreement.
axioms.citation: 2020 MOU between WVDP and DNC RBC, p. 2

rule_summary: As the designated compliance officer, this individual had a fiduciary duty to act as a neutral arbiter and ensure the process was open and fair. Using this position of trust to secure a role with procedural control for oneself is a fundamental breach of that duty.

case_facts.text: The script, authored by Selina Vickers, directs a committee member to state: 'I nominate Selina Vickers for Parliamentarian/Secretary.'
The script provides a verbatim endorsement for the member to read, which concludes, 'I can think of no one else remotely qualified to do this particular work.'

logic_chain: Selina Vickers was the officer officially appointed under the MOU to 'oversee and direct compliance.'
Her primary duty in this role was to ensure a fair and open process.
She used her position as the architect of the meeting to write a script that directed her own nomination to a key procedural role.
This action constitutes a direct breach of her duty as a neutral compliance officer, as she used her authority to install herself in a position of power.
[DJ-MARK] The designated referee of the process rigged the game for herself.
violation: As the designated compliance officer, Selina Vickers fundamentally betrayed her role by orchestrating her own appointment. This action was not merely a conflict of interest; it was a direct breach of her fiduciary duty under the MOU to guarantee a fair process, thereby corrupting the committee's procedural legitimacy at its inception.

title: PROOF: Script Reveals Pre-Planned Strategy to Control Meeting and Dissent
stakes: The committee was structured to execute a pre-determined agenda and manage any opposition, not to foster the inclusive participation required by party rules.
thesis: The formation script included pre-planned tactics to control dissent and challenge attendees, proving the meeting was designed to execute a private agenda, not facilitate open participation.

axioms.text: The DNC Charter mandates that 'All meetings of... all other official Party committees, commissions and bodies shall be open to the public'.

rule_summary: The DNC Charter's rule for open meetings requires a process that allows for spontaneous, good-faith participation, not a pre-planned system to control who can attend and to manage anticipated opposition.

case_facts.text: The script anticipates that the meeting may be closed to the public and provides a challenge to be used against observers: 'Ask: 'I notice there are people other than caucus co-chairs present. I thought this meeting was solely for co-chairs.''
The script anticipates criticism from Party Chair Belinda Biafore, pre-characterizing it as 'scolding': 'She may scold you for the caucus meetings last night'.
The script provides response strategies for managing this anticipated opposition rather than addressing its substance.

logic_chain: The script contains a pre-planned tactic to challenge the presence of observers at what should be an open meeting.
The script anticipates opposition from the Party Chair and pre-characterizes it as 'scolding' to trivialize legitimate concerns.
It provides response strategies for managing this opposition.
This proves the meeting was designed to execute a pre-determined outcome despite anticipated objections.
[DJ-MARK] The organizers built opposition management into their plan, violating principles of open deliberation.
violation: The script's prepared tactics for managing participation and its pre-emptive characterization of criticism violate the 'open meetings' principle of the DNC Charter. This proves the meeting was designed to control outcomes, not facilitate democratic participation.

title: PROOF: DNC Supervisor and Challenger Rep Maintained a Pattern of Coordinated Control
stakes: The entire WVDP reform process was compromised from its inception by a coordinated effort between the DNC's designated supervisor and the complainant's representative.
thesis: DNC RBC member Harold Ickes and Selina Vickers engaged in sustained coordination that evolved into strategic advice to neutralize elected representatives.

axioms.text: The MOU required an 'open and transparent process' with 'full, timely, and equal opportunity' for participation.
The RBC was tasked with impartial 'supervision and technical assistance.'
Harold Ickes served on the DNC Rules & Bylaws Committee.
axioms.citation: Corporate Lobbyists Control the Rules at the DNC, Sludge, Feb. 28, 2020

axioms.text: Selina Vickers served as the 'non-voting representative of the Challengers.'

rule_summary: A supervisor's duty of impartiality prohibits providing partisan strategic advice to one party against another.

case_facts.text: Harold Ickes and Selina Vickers co-hosted a political training event during the MOU implementation period.
In a recorded meeting, Harold Ickes stated: 'I've said to Selina god knows how many times you know what at bottom you gotta out vote' Seth and Mari.
Mary Ann Claytor documented that Ickes 'advised Selina to 'outvote' Seth, Mari, and others.'
case_facts.citation: Email from Mary Ann Claytor, Sept. 23, 2021

logic_chain: The DNC supervisor and Challengers' representative established professional collaboration.
This evolved into Ickes providing repeated strategic advice to 'out vote' specific members.
The targeted members were elected minority caucus representatives.
This converted supervision into partisan strategy.
[DJ-MARK] The supervisor became an active participant rather than neutral overseer.
violation: Harold Ickes' repeated advice to 'out vote' elected representatives violated his duty of impartial supervision under the MOU.

title: PROOF: Defamation Campaign Targeted Minority Representatives
stakes: Indigenous and Black representatives faced a coordinated defamation campaign designed to destroy their reputations and force their resignations, using tactics that specifically harm marginalized communities.
thesis: Leadership orchestrated a defamation campaign against minority representatives, spreading false claims about violence and using concealed coordination to amplify attacks.

axioms.text: False accusations of violence against marginalized people carry particular harm given historical stereotypes and systemic bias.
The DNC Charter requires ethical conduct that 'reflects creditably upon the office.'
Defamation includes false statements of fact that damage reputation.
Marginalized communities face disproportionate harm from coordinated harassment.

rule_summary: Spreading false accusations and orchestrating harassment campaigns violates ethical standards and causes particular harm when targeted at marginalized representatives.

case_facts.text: Scripts attacking Indigenous representatives were distributed with concealment instructions: '[if you use this... DO NOT FORWARD THIS EMAIL].'
case_facts.citation: Email from Selina Vickers to Kristin Loken, Aug 17, 2021

case_facts.text: False claims were spread that an Indigenous Caucus chair was 'dangerous' and 'capable of violence.'
case_facts.citation: Email from Seth Sturm documenting rumors, Sept 17, 2021

case_facts.text: A sustained public campaign labeled the Indigenous chair a 'toxic bully' with a 'calendar of posts ready to go.'
The Black Caucus co-chair cited these 'vicious' attacks as forcing her resignation.
case_facts.citation: Mary Ann Claytor Resignation Email, Sept 18, 2021

case_facts.text: Members reported being 'reluctant to speak publicly for fear of retaliation and future harassment.'
The Indigenous chair reported the attacks had 'done real damage' requiring him to defend against violence accusations.

logic_chain: False accusations of violence were spread about Indigenous representatives.
These accusations weaponize harmful stereotypes against marginalized people.
The attacks were coordinated through concealed scripts and sustained campaigns.
Both Indigenous and Black leaders were targeted and harmed.
The Black Caucus co-chair was forced to resign.
A climate of fear silenced other marginalized members.
[DJ-MARK] This constitutes targeted harassment designed to eliminate minority representation.
violation: The coordinated defamation campaign, including false violence accusations against Indigenous representatives and attacks that forced the Black Caucus co-chair's resignation, constitutes targeted harassment of marginalized leaders. This violated ethical standards and weaponized harmful stereotypes to destroy minority representation in the committee.

title: PROOF: Minority Caucuses Were Excluded from Key Subcommittees
stakes: Minority caucus chairs were denied participation in governance structures.
thesis: Leadership systematically excluded specific caucus chairs from subcommittees after reversing a democratic vote.

axioms.text: The MOU mandated 'full participation by all Democrats, with particular concern for minority groups.'
Once adopted, a motion stands until properly reconsidered.

rule_summary: Excluding minority representatives from governance violates the MOU's participation mandate.

case_facts.text: The committee voted for a volunteer-based subcommittee system.
Leadership subsequently declared 'subcommittee membership will be by appointment.'
Indigenous and Black caucus chairs were denied subcommittee seats.
The Board of Appeals found members were improperly denied subcommittee seats.
case_facts.citation: WVDP Board of Appeals Resolution, Nov. 29, 2021

logic_chain: A democratic vote established a volunteer system.
Leadership unilaterally declared an appointment system.
They used this to exclude specific caucus chairs.
The Board of Appeals confirmed this was improper.
[DJ-MARK] Democratic decisions were overturned to exclude minority representatives.
violation: The reversal of a democratic vote and exclusion of minority caucus chairs violated the MOU's participation mandate.

title: PROOF: Bylaws Mislabeled to Circumvent Notice Requirements
stakes: Members were denied their right to review and consult on fundamental governance changes through deliberate mislabeling.
thesis: Substantive bylaws were mislabeled as 'procedural rules' to circumvent the 30-day notice requirement.

axioms.text: WVDP Bylaws require 30 days written notice for amendments.
axioms.citation: WVDP Bylaws, Article XI, Section A

axioms.text: Bylaws define organizational structure and continuing governance.
Rules of order govern single meetings; bylaws establish ongoing authority.
Notice requirements protect members' right to deliberate.

rule_summary: Rules granting authority between meetings or establishing committee structures are bylaws requiring 30-day notice, regardless of their label.

case_facts.text: Documents titled 'DRAFT Procedural Rules' were circulated less than 24 hours before the August 17, 2021 meeting.
Rule 13 granted Co-Chairs 'all the authority of the Affirmative Action Committee... between meetings.'
case_facts.citation: DRAFT Procedural Rules for august meeting.pdf

case_facts.text: Rule 14 established subcommittee appointment and removal procedures.
case_facts.citation: DRAFT Procedural Rules for august meeting.pdf

case_facts.text: A member asked during the meeting: 'Why weren't they sent earlier so that we had an opportunity to read them?'
Another member stated: 'it's not a procedural rule for handling this meeting.'

logic_chain: Rules 13 and 14 granted continuing authority and established structures.
Such rules are bylaws by definition, not procedural rules.
Bylaws require 30 days notice under WVDP rules.
The documents were provided with less than 24 hours notice.
The mislabeling as 'procedural' bypassed notice requirements.
Members identified this violation during the meeting.
[DJ-MARK] AAC leadership attempted to pass bylaws through improper procedure and without proper notice.
violation: Mislabeling bylaws as 'procedural rules' to avoid the 30-day notice requirement violated WVDP Bylaws Article XI and denied members their deliberative rights.

title: PROOF: Undisclosed Conflict of Interest Invalidated Proceedings
stakes: A procedural vote requiring a neutral presider was overseen by an external actor with an undisclosed professional relationship to an internal faction, which ultimately led to the invalidation of the proceedings.
thesis: Leadership invited an external actor, Larry Taylor, to preside over a critical meeting without disclosing his professional relationship with the committee's parliamentarian.

axioms.text: Larry Taylor served as a parliamentarian trainer with the Professional Development Program.
Taylor and Selina Vickers were professional colleagues.
axioms.citation: Email Correspondence between S. Vickers and L. Taylor

axioms.text: Presiding officers must maintain strict impartiality.
Persons in positions of trust must disclose potential conflicts.
The Board of Appeals ruled the August meeting invalid.

rule_summary: A presiding officer must be neutral and disclose any relationships that could affect impartiality. A failure to disclose such conflicts compromises the integrity of the proceedings.

case_facts.text: Larry Taylor was invited to preside over the meeting where restrictive rules were adopted.
Taylor's professional relationship with Parliamentarian Vickers was not disclosed to the committee.
Taylor specialized in training on procedural tactics.
The committee had previously rejected similar restrictive measures in prior proceedings.
case_facts.citation: AAC Meeting Minutes re: Prior Rejected Measures

case_facts.text: The Board of Appeals subsequently ruled the meeting invalid, citing improper procedures.

logic_chain: An external officer presided over the meeting.
This officer had undisclosed professional ties to the Parliamentarian, an active participant in the matters being discussed.
The officer's specific expertise in procedural tactics was also not disclosed.
The committee had rejected similar measures in prior proceedings.
The undisclosed relationships created an appearance of bias.
The party's Board of Appeals confirmed the procedural invalidity of the meeting.
[DJ-MARK] The failure to disclose these conflicts of interest invalidated the entire process.
violation: Installing a presiding officer with an undisclosed professional relationship to an internal faction violated the requirement for a neutral presider. This failure of disclosure compromised the democratic process and resulted in an invalid meeting, as confirmed by the Board of Appeals.

title: PROOF: Unreported Financial Activity - The Scholarship Program
stakes: A PAC concealed its scholarship program from required disclosures, hiding who funded it and who benefited from its activities.
thesis: A New Day PAC failed to report any financial activity for its publicly announced scholarship program, a violation of state disclosure laws.

axioms.text: All expenditures made by a political committee must be publicly reported.
Any 'thing of value' received by a political committee must be publicly reported as an in-kind contribution.

rule_summary: State law requires political committees to report all financial transactions. A scholarship program necessarily involves either direct expenditures or in-kind contributions of services. Failure to report either transaction type violates campaign finance law.

case_facts.text: A New Day PAC solicited applications for a formal scholarship program for third-party training on August 22, 2023.
The PAC's Q3 2023 sworn financial report shows zero expenditures to the trainer for scholarship payments.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing

case_facts.text: The same sworn report shows zero in-kind contributions from the trainer for donated training slots.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing

case_facts.text: The PAC had previously paid this same trainer for 'Consultant Fees,' establishing a documented financial relationship.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q4 2022 Filing

logic_chain: The PAC publicly offered scholarships for training on August 22, 2023.
Any scholarship transaction must be publicly reported as either an 'expenditure' or an in-kind 'thing of value.'
The PAC's sworn Q3 2023 financial report contains neither expenditures for scholarships nor in-kind contributions for training.
The absence of any reported transaction means the PAC concealed this program from required public disclosure.
[DJ-MARK] The PAC's sworn financial disclosure reports omit all activity related to its scholarship program.
violation: A New Day PAC violated state campaign finance law by failing to report the financial activity of its scholarship program in its Q3 2023 filing. This violation denies the public its statutory right to transparency and renders the PAC's sworn statement materially incomplete.

title: PROOF: PAC Used Party Resources Without Reporting an In-Kind Contribution
stakes: A private PAC received an undisclosed subsidy from the state party.
thesis: The 'A New Day' PAC used an official party email list for fundraising and failed to report the required in-kind contribution.

axioms.text: Any 'thing of value' provided to a political committee must be reported as an in-kind contribution.

case_facts.text: A promotional email for the 'A New Day' PAC was sent using the official WVDP County Chairs email list on August 22, 2023[cite: 74, 80].
case_facts.citation: A New Day Training Email, Aug 22, 2023

case_facts.text: The PAC's sworn Q3 2023 financial report for this period reported $0.00 in in-kind contributions.
case_facts.citation: A New Day PAC Q3 2023 Filing, p. 1

violation: The 'A New Day' PAC violated state campaign finance law by failing to report the WVDP email list usage as an in-kind contribution.
